In fact, chimps who have learned some sign language have been known to communicate with each other and with other apes as well as with humans, and have been known to teach the signs they know to other chimps and offspring, even molding the other animal’s hands to demonstrate and help them learn the signs. Apes can learn to use tools, including hammers and wrenches, and wild chimps have been known to make and use primitive spears. She is a great ape, after all, and this will show that apes can develop the ability to domesticate animals. Another thing our replacements will need to have mastered.Search Koko on You Tube and you can get a great deal more insight into the life and intelligence of this amazing creature and her friends. That gorillas could climb the evolutionary ladder and repopulate the Earth is not impossible.But we have chosen chimps to replace us. They have a numerical advantage and are at least as intelligent. Like humans, chimps sometimes fight wars with other groups of their species, and in a coordinated manner. This, at first glance, does not seem to be a positive thing and for us it certainly is not - however, for primitive societies it ensures that the strongest and most intelligent - those most capable of advancing the species - are the ones who survive and pass along their genes to future generations.Over the eons, one group of tool using chimpanzees teach their offspring the arts of tool making, hunting and gathering, they discover ways to control and use fire, learn that when seeds are dropped, they sometimes sprout and grow into plants which produce the same food they were eating in the place the seeds were dropped and one chimp has the idea to save some seeds, mark and clear a small area and put them on the ground. Noticing the birds eating the seeds, she goes back with more and covers them with soil so the birds and small animals won’t get them. The plants come up and within weeks or months she sees mature plants bearing the same food from which the seeds came. Now she doesn’t have to go search through the forest to find food. Agriculture is born, and she rushes to show off her discovery to others, who follow her lead.While some of the group is off making tools, some hunting, others busy doing other things, some of them get the idea that if they offer a toolmaker food, perhaps he will offer them a tool. Trade is born, and spreads throughout the tribe.All this time, the primitive hoots and gestures have changed to include new sounds and gestures for each new concept. The language has gotten more and more complicated, and now there are sounds and gestures which express more thoughts and more complex sentences. These ‘words’ are taught to the young.At some point, perhaps idly scratching at the ground with a stick, a chimp notices a design left by his stick in the soil which reminds him of something. Excited, he pictures a tree in his mind and very deliberately scrawls out with a stick, the outline of a tree. He runs and gets a friend, brings him back and points at the design he drew in the dirt, then points to a tree and his friend picks up a stick and draws something else. Others notice, and so, both art and writing are born. Thousands of years later, descendants of that tribe have developed symbols for all the words they use, and a technique for applying pigment to rocks and tree bark. A written language is born and taught to the young. Knowledge can now be recorded and passed on to later generations, a history can be kept, and in the caves in which they have learned to find shelter, they record it on the wall.As the tribe grows in size, resources grow short and so a few move out beyond their original territory. New tribes are founded in this way, as the process repeats itself and the species begins to spread. Curious members of the tribe begin to wonder what lies there, toward the edge of the world, and they begin longer and longer walks exploring. Oddly, as they walk further and further toward the edge of the world, the edge of the world seems always just as far away. The explorers find fertile valleys, lush forests, and occasionally decayed ruins and artifacts left behind by humans (though they know nothing of humans and do not understand what they see). They see great rivers and follow them to the ocean. Water all the way to the edge of the world. Everywhere they travel, they see new and different things, and whenever they find a place that would make a good home, they go back and tell the tribe all about the wonders they see. Tempted by the promise of a better life, at times small groups leave their tribe and set out to find the next suitable place, where they settle and reproduce. At times, some natural disaster strikes and the people (for they are no longer just chimpanzees, they have become people) affected must flee their homes to find safety elsewhere. Wars with other tribes occur from time to time, but the species persists and continues to spread across what is, by now, mostly one great landmass, covered in dense forest and populated with a multitude of different species you and I would barely recognize, both predator and prey, living in perfect balance.These new people have long since run out of caves in which to find shelter and security. They had often found themselves in areas far away from the nearest mountain or opening in rock. At some point their ancestors began using tree branches to erect shelters, the insides of which gave them the comfort and shelter they remembered finding in the caves. Later on, their descendants started covering the tree branches with animal hides, then started piling stones up, forming walls, and at last they had returned to the caves (sort of).Along the way, the many languages, both spoken and written had evolved with this new kind of people, becoming more and more complex as they did. Other animals had been taken and kept alive, and it was found that they would breed in captivity, making meat available to the tribe even when hunting was poor. Someone had noticed that when certain male animals bred with certain females, the offspring carried certain traits, so selective breeding had been discovered. Elsewhere, someone had grown tired of searching for the nests of birds and decided to capture and keep the birds themselves. Instead of eating the birds - which had been what had made the nests so hard to find - she made nests for them herself and as they laid eggs, she had harvested them. She had decided to let some of the eggs hatch instead of going out and catching more birds. She too had noticed that certain pairings resulted in larger eggs or plumper birds (the birds reproduced so fast that before she knew it she had both plenty of eggs and birds to eat as well).The small settlements had grown and become villages. Some of the explorers had become simple travelers, going from village to village sharing news and knowledge. The travelers had noticed that some villages had plenty of some things and a shortage of others, while other villages had plenty of what was in short supply and and a need for things found in plenty elsewhere.
